sentence: Home improvement warehouse operators The Home Depot, Inc. ( HD ) and Lowe's Companies, Inc. ( LOW ) both saw their earnings estimates raised on Wednesday by analysts at FBR Capital Markets.
The firm noted the stocks are not reliant on back-to-school or holiday shopping trends, unlike many other retailers.
An FBR analyst comments, "60%+ of the annual EBIT is behind us for HD and LOW (spring is Christmas).

So, with August sales to date likely better than last month, July, sales and earnings risk for the home improvement chains is significantly lower than that of other cyclical retailers whose profits are more highly indexed to (1) back-to-school and (2) the holidays.
The annual profit mix percentages tend to be the opposite for the other types of retailers.
This sets HD and LOW up with a bird-in-the-hand outlook, relative to peers, in our opinion."

Continuing, "We revise our 2010 EPS estimate for HD to $1.91 from $1.83, and this compares with the Street consensus estimate of $1.89 and guidance of $1.92 (adjusted to exclude $0.02 per share of one-time items).
For 2011E, we revise our EPS to $2.14 from $2.08, and this compares with the Street mean estimate of $2.21.
For Lowe's, we revise our 2010 EPS estimate to $1.38 from $1.32, and this compares with the Street consensus EPS estimate of $1.42.
For 2011E, we revise our EPS estimate to $1.53 from $1.50, versus the Street consensus EPS estimate of $1.69."
Home Depot and Lowe's shares were mostly flat in premarket trading Wednesday.
Shares of HD have a 3.31% dividend yield, based on last night's closing stock price of $28.31.
Shares of LOW have a 2.20% dividend yield, based on last night's closing stock price of $19.99.
Both The Home Depot, Inc. ( HD ) and Lowe's Companies, Inc. ( LOW ) are rated "Neutral," holding Dividend.com DARSâ„¢ Ratings of 3.4 out of 5 stars.
